title: 114_hr3037
content: The "Hospice Care Access Improvement Act of 2015" is also known as the Hospice Payment Reform Demonstration Program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a 1-year demonstration program in fiscal year 2016 to test proposed hospice payment methodology revisions. The revisions aim to determine hospice payment rates and quality reporting requirements. One Medicare administrative contractor will be selected to carry out the program. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration program in fiscal year 2016 to test proposed hospice payment methodology revisions. The program will evaluate the impact on patient care quality, access to hospice care, and submit a report to Congress by March 31, 2017 with recommendations for legislative and administrative action. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration program in fiscal year 2016 to test proposed hospice payment methodology revisions. No revisions to the hospice payment methodology shall be made for fiscal years 2016 and 2017, except for the demonstration program. The Secretary will implement the proposed hospice payment methodology revisions for fiscal year 2018 after evaluating the demonstration program. SEC. 3. HOSPICE PROGRAM INTEGRITY. The Secretary will implement a medical review process for hospice care provided by identified hospice programs, considering various factors. The Secretary will evaluate hospice programs based on factors like patient discharge rates after 120-180 days of care, skilled hospice care visits at the end of life, and per-patient expenditures under this title. The Secretary will evaluate hospice programs based on factors like patient discharge rates after 120-180 days of care, skilled hospice care visits at the end of life, and per-patient expenditures under this title. The Secretary shall develop guidance for hospice programs to reduce hospital admissions. The Secretary will evaluate hospice programs based on factors like patient discharge rates after 120-180 days of care, skilled hospice care visits at the end of life, and per-patient expenditures under this title. Additionally, hospice programs are encouraged to develop interventions to reduce hospital admissions and visits to hospital emergency departments. The amendment allows registered nurses employed by hospice programs to provide pre-hospice evaluation and counseling services in consultation with the interdisciplinary group. The Secretary will evaluate the impact of this amendment. The evaluation will assess the impact of amendments on hospital admission rates, hospice care utilization, and length of stay in hospice programs for patients under section 1812(a)(5) of the Social Security Act. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress with the results. Additionally, there is an amendment to expand hospice care access for residents using skilled nursing facilities under section 1819 of the Social Security Act. The facility must make an effort to contract with multiple hospice programs for residents. Residents must be fully informed of any financial interest the facility has in a hospice program. The amendments made by this subsection apply to skilled nursing facilities in operation 1 year after the enactment of this Act. Section 1861(ee)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions relating to hospice care availability for individuals likely to need hospice care. The amendments made by this subsection include adding hospice care availability to home health services for discharges occurring 90 days after the enactment of this Act.
